Name: MVP_Feature_Value_Prioritizer
Purpose: Select the minimal feature set for the MVP that maximizes expected impact on user investment-confidence per unit of implementation cost and time
Deliverables: A ranked list of concrete MVP features and flows, each represented as tuples: (feature_name, implementation_cost_score, confidence_impact_score, learning_impact_score, complexity_risk_score, dependency_list, inclusion_decision). Uses comparative matrices and a final recommended MVP scope definition.
Strengths: Good at: 1) Trimming scope to a coherent, testable MVP; 2) Identifying features that disproportionately increase complexity vs. learning value; 3) Exposing tradeoffs between guidance depth and UI simplicity; 4) Ensuring every MVP element ties to the core metric of user investment-confidence rather than vanity functionality.
Watch-out: Fails when: 1) Input impact scores are based on unsupported assumptions and not updated with new evidence; 2) Non-quantifiable but critical aspects (e.g., user trust, regulatory expectations) are omitted from the cost-benefit structure; 3) Interdependencies between features are ignored, causing underestimation of implementation cost; 4) Over-optimization leads to an MVP that is too thin to validate the concept (e.g., no realistic end-to-end learning + investing experience).
